key_points: Former President Donald Trump suggested on a podcast that Alec Baldwin's fatal shooting of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins on the 'Rust' set might have been intentional.
The incident occurred in October when Baldwin fired a prop gun containing a live round, resulting in Hutchins's death.
Trump expressed his suspicion on the conservative podcast hosted by Chris Stigall, questioning why Baldwin would point a gun at the cinematographer instead of a fellow actor.
Authorities are still investigating the incident, and no charges have been filed against Baldwin, who has stated he is 'fully cooperating' with the investigation.
Trump criticized Baldwin's character, referring to him as a 'cuckoo-bird' and a 'nutjob', and insinuated Baldwin may have had something to do with the incident.
Trump elaborated on his skepticism about the handling of the gun, questioning the rationale behind pointing a gun at someone not involved in the movie and pulling the trigger.
Baldwin had previously expressed his shock and sadness over the tragic event, emphasizing his sympathy for Hutchins's family and his willingness to support them.
Following the incident, Baldwin has advocated for a police presence on movie and television sets to monitor firearms safety, a proposal made through a tweet from his art foundation.
No specific dateline or location provided for where or when the podcast interview with Trump took place.
The article reflects on both Trump's controversial comments and Baldwin's responses to the tragic incident.
